FeedItems.Title: Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org
FeedItems.Summary:
NuGet.org will begin requiring two-factor authentication for accounts starting March 8th.
The post Requiring two-factor authentication on NuGet.org appeared first on The NuGet Blog.

FeedItems.Title: Add a README to Your NuGet Package
FeedItems.Summary:

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Self-hosted Bug]: error 400 on register or login" (#9091) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

Other

### Describe the bug

I compiled NuGetGallery and launched it on IIS Server, removed "rewrite" section from web.config, but when I am trying to register or login it shows error 400. If I launch NuGetGallery on IIS Express from visual studio it works fine. 

### Repro Steps

Run NuGetGallery on IIS server


### Expected Behavior

Register without error

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[ReleasePrep][2022.04.11] RI dev to main" (#9090) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened pull request "[ReleasePrep][2022.04.11] RI dev to main" (#9090) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Merged pull request "Make sure account and package links on the support requests page use the same host" (#9089) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Admin-only instance in support requests links accounts and packages to the originating host (www.nuget.org) which creates complications for processing support requests.
This change replaces absolute URLs with relative ones that works around the issue.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: TestPacManPreviewUpdateWithAllowedVersionsConstraint started failing due to new package version" (#11739) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

NuGet 6.3.0.10

### Worked before?

Yes

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Run test TestPacManPreviewUpdateWithAllowedVersionsConstraint located at NuGet.Client\test\NuGet.Core.Tests\NuGet.PackageManagement.Test\NuGetPackageManagerTests.cs

Few hours ago, version 2.0.0 of Microsoft.Web.Infrastructure was published https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Web.Infrastructure/

Current test has a packages.config which depends on version 1.0.0 of that package:

```
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
  <packages>
    <package id='Microsoft.Web.Infrastructure' version='1.0.0.0' targetFramework='net45' />
    <package id='Newtonsoft.Json' version='4.5.11' allowedVersions='[4.0,5.0)' targetFramework='net45' />
  </packages> 
```

Test is asking for highest package version available: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/e70d3c6167fc1c878acee98050784726152e4a31/test/NuGet.Core.Tests/NuGet.PackageManagement.Test/NuGetPackageManagerTests.cs#L3984

I am wondering if we either

1) Add a package range to allow only package versions [1.0.0, 2.0.0)
2) Modify test to run only on test-generated, local packages

Also, this test runs on nuget.org V2 protocol. 

### Verbose Logs

```shell
Message: 
Assert.Equal() Failure
Expected: 0
Actual:   2

  Stack Trace: 
<TestPacManPreviewUpdateWithAllowedVersionsConstraint>d__80.MoveNext() line 4038
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "GeneratePathProperty properties should end with a trailing slash" (#8871) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe): `msbuild -t:Restore`

NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx): `5.5.0-preview.1.6319+ba2a72ac9afd9e7260798a6ad14088297570b350.ba2a72ac9afd9e7260798a6ad14088297570b350`

Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version: no

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

When a package is referenced with `GeneratePathProperty="true"`, a property based on the package name is created in `.nuget.g.props`. The value of the property is the path to the root of the expanded package on disk.

Currently, this looks like

```xml
  <PropertyGroup Condition=" '$(ExcludeRestorePackageImports)' != 'true' ">
    <PkgEnterpriseLibrary_TransientFaultHandling_Core Condition=" '$(PkgEnterpriseLibrary_TransientFaultHandling_Core)' == '' ">C:\Users\raines\.nuget\packages\enterpriselibrary.transientfaulthandling.core\1.0.0</PkgEnterpriseLibrary_TransientFaultHandling_Core>
  </PropertyGroup>
```

Ideally this would **end with a path-separator slash**. That makes it easier to avoid referencing the property with a glob like `$(PkgWhatever)\**` which expands to `{root of disk}\**` which causes MSBuild to read every file on the disk, with possibly destructive effects. If the property is undefined `$(PkgWhateverWithTrailingSlash)**` is at least restricted to the project directory.

Various properties in common targets follow this convention for this reason.

## Other suggested things

An obvious question is "should MSBuild allow this?". It's hard to definitively say "no", but we're considering logging and some other options: microsoft/msbuild#3642 microsoft/msbuild#3204

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: TestPacManPreviewUpdateWithAllowedVersionsConstraint started failing due to new package version" (#11739) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

NuGet 6.3.0.10

### Worked before?

Yes

### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Repro Steps & Context

Run test TestPacManPreviewUpdateWithAllowedVersionsConstraint located at NuGet.Client\test\NuGet.Core.Tests\NuGet.PackageManagement.Test\NuGetPackageManagerTests.cs

Few hours ago, version 2.0.0 of Microsoft.Web.Infrastructure was published https://www.nuget.org/packages/Microsoft.Web.Infrastructure/

Current test has a packages.config which depends on version 1.0.0 of that package:

```
<?xml version='1.0' encoding='utf-8'?>
  <packages>
    <package id='Microsoft.Web.Infrastructure' version='1.0.0.0' targetFramework='net45' />
    <package id='Newtonsoft.Json' version='4.5.11' allowedVersions='[4.0,5.0)' targetFramework='net45' />
  </packages> 
```

I am wondering if we either

1) Add a package range to allow only package versions [1.0.0, 2.0.0)
2) Modify test to run only on test-generated, local packages

Also, this test runs on nuget.org V2 protocol. 

### Verbose Logs

```shell
Message: 
Assert.Equal() Failure
Expected: 0
Actual:   2

  Stack Trace: 
<TestPacManPreviewUpdateWithAllowedVersionsConstraint>d__80.MoveNext() line 4038
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
TaskAwaiter.ThrowForNonSuccess(Task task)
TaskAwaiter.HandleNonSuccessAndDebuggerNotification(Task task)
--- End of stack trace from previous location where exception was thrown ---
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Bug]: Cannot compile NuGet.Client due to duplicated PackageReference" (#11738) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

Other/NA

### Product Version

VS Version 17.3.0 Preview 1.0 [32410.47.main], NuGet 6.3.0.10

### Worked before?

Yes

### Impact

I'm unable to use this version

### Repro Steps & Context

1. Clone NuGet.Client to dev in commit: e70d3c6167fc1c878acee98050784726152e4a31
1. Open Dev PowerShell for VS 2022 IntPreview
2. Run `cd path\to\repo`
3. Run `git clean -xdf; .\configure.ps1 -Force; .\build.ps1 -Fast -SkipUnitTest -Binlog`

### Expected

Code compiles

### Actual

```
C:\src\NuGet.Client.pmc\test\NuGet.Clients.Tests\NuGet.PackageManagement.UI.Test\NuGet.PackageManagement.UI.Test.csproj : error NU1504: Duplicate 'PackageReference' items found. Remove the duplicate items or u
```

### Verbose Logs

```shell
Attaching binlog
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "The trailing slash in GeneratePathProperty causes ROBOCOPY failures" (#11737) at NuGet/Home

Events.RelatedBody: We announced plans to require tFA on all accounts on NuGet.org. Details in the [blog post](https://devblogs.microsoft.com/nuget/requiring-two-factor-authentication-on-nuget-org/).
